material.mattext: Nina's perfectionism drives her to practice until she bleeds. According to Feldman Barrett et al. (2001), how does her apparent inability to distinguish between productive striving and self-destruction relate to emotion differentiation?
High differentiation allows her to push through pain signals
Low differentiation prevents her from recognizing when anxiety has crossed into harmful territory, impairing adaptive regulation
Dancers are trained to suppress emotion differentiation
Physical pain and emotional satisfaction are inherently undifferentiated

Correct!

Feldman Barrett et al.'s research on emotion differentiation shows that people who can distinguish between similar emotional states make better self-regulatory decisions. Nina cannot differentiate between productive anxiety (motivating practice) and destructive anxiety (driving self-harm). Her low differentiation means all anxiety feels the same, preventing her from recognizing when she's crossed from healthy striving into pathology. She can't tell when "enough" becomes "too much."

The correct answer is B.

Feldman Barrett et al.'s research on emotion differentiation shows that people who can distinguish between similar emotional states make better self-regulatory decisions. Nina cannot differentiate between productive anxiety (motivating practice) and destructive anxiety (driving self-harm). Her low differentiation means all anxiety feels the same, preventing her from recognizing when she's crossed from healthy striving into pathology. She can't tell when "enough" becomes "too much."

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Reverses the relationship. HIGH differentiation would help her recognize when to stop, not continue.
  • C: No evidence for this claim. If anything, artistic training might enhance emotional awareness.
  • D: These are distinguishable for most people. Nina's inability to distinguish is pathological, not universal.
Nina's hallucinations escalate throughout the film. According to Kalokerinos et al. (2019), why might low negative emotion differentiation predict more severe symptom progression?
Undifferentiated emotions are inherently more intense
Low differentiators seek more extreme stimulation
Low differentiators use emotion regulation strategies ineffectively, with all strategies associated with INCREASED rather than decreased negative affect
Differentiation protects against genetic vulnerability to psychosis

Correct!

Kalokerinos et al.'s (2019) key finding is that low differentiators don't just struggle with one regulation strategy - they struggle with ALL strategies. For low differentiators, even typically adaptive strategies like reappraisal are associated with increased negative affect. Nina tries everything: distraction, suppression, situation avoidance - but nothing works because she can't accurately identify what she's feeling. Each failed regulation attempt may contribute to symptom escalation.

The correct answer is C.

Kalokerinos et al.'s (2019) key finding is that low differentiators don't just struggle with one regulation strategy - they struggle with ALL strategies. For low differentiators, even typically adaptive strategies like reappraisal are associated with increased negative affect. Nina tries everything: distraction, suppression, situation avoidance - but nothing works because she can't accurately identify what she's feeling. Each failed regulation attempt may contribute to symptom escalation.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Not what the research shows. The intensity isn't necessarily higher; the regulation is less effective.
  • B: This describes sensation-seeking, not differentiation. These are separate constructs.
  • D: No evidence for gene-environment interaction involving differentiation and psychosis specifically.

Erica Sayers (Nina's mother) gave up her ballet career to raise Nina and now lives vicariously through her. Which psychological mechanism best explains how this dynamic contributes to Nina's pathology?
Genetic transmission of anxiety disorders
Modeling of maladaptive perfectionism
Fusion of identities preventing Nina from developing autonomous purpose and self-regulation
Classical conditioning of dance with punishment

Correct!

Erica's vicarious living through Nina creates a fusion of identities that prevents Nina from developing autonomous purpose. Nina's goals aren't truly hers - they're her mother's goals imposed on her. This lack of self-concordance (Kashdan et al., 2024) means Nina pursues achievement without genuine personal investment, making self-regulation harder because she's regulating for someone else's dream, not her own.

The correct answer is C.

Erica's vicarious living through Nina creates a fusion of identities that prevents Nina from developing autonomous purpose. Nina's goals aren't truly hers - they're her mother's goals imposed on her. This lack of self-concordance (Kashdan et al., 2024) means Nina pursues achievement without genuine personal investment, making self-regulation harder because she's regulating for someone else's dream, not her own.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: While anxiety may have genetic components, this doesn't explain the MECHANISM by which the mother-daughter dynamic contributes.
  • B: Partially relevant, but modeling explains learning patterns, not the deeper identity fusion.
  • D: Oversimplifies the psychological dynamic. The relationship is about identity, not conditioned associations.
Thomas Leroy tells Nina she must "lose herself" to embody the Black Swan. This artistic directive is psychologically dangerous because:
Method acting always produces mental illness
The Black Swan role is inherently traumatizing
Nina interprets metaphorical instruction literally, believing actual identity dissolution is required rather than emotional access
Directors intentionally destabilize performers

Correct!

Thomas means "lose yourself" metaphorically - access emotions you normally suppress. Nina interprets it literally - actually dissolve your identity. This literalization of metaphor reflects her concrete thinking and poor reality testing. When Thomas says "seduce me," he means perform seduction; Nina considers actually seducing him. Her inability to process figurative artistic language as figurative pushes her toward actual identity dissolution.

The correct answer is C.

Thomas means "lose yourself" metaphorically - access emotions you normally suppress. Nina interprets it literally - actually dissolve your identity. This literalization of metaphor reflects her concrete thinking and poor reality testing. When Thomas says "seduce me," he means perform seduction; Nina considers actually seducing him. Her inability to process figurative artistic language as figurative pushes her toward actual identity dissolution.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Many actors use method techniques without developing psychosis. It's Nina's interpretation, not the technique itself.
  • B: The role itself is demanding but not inherently pathogenic. Many dancers perform it without harm.
  • D: Thomas may be exploitative, but there's no evidence he intends to cause psychosis.
Nina sees her own face on other dancers and in mirrors with distorted features. This symptom most specifically suggests which psychological process?
Generalized anxiety about competition
Projection of unwanted characteristics onto others
Disturbed self-representation and body image with features of depersonalization
Normal performance anxiety under pressure

Correct!

Nina's visual experiences specifically involve SELF-representation - she sees her own face on others, her reflection transforms, her body morphs. This pattern suggests disturbance in the neural systems that maintain stable self-representation. The term "depersonalization" captures the sense of self becoming unfamiliar or unreal. This goes beyond anxiety or projection to suggest a fundamental disturbance in how she perceives and represents herself.

The correct answer is C.

Nina's visual experiences specifically involve SELF-representation - she sees her own face on others, her reflection transforms, her body morphs. This pattern suggests disturbance in the neural systems that maintain stable self-representation. The term "depersonalization" captures the sense of self becoming unfamiliar or unreal. This goes beyond anxiety or projection to suggest a fundamental disturbance in how she perceives and represents herself.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Anxiety doesn't typically produce these specific visual disturbances of self-perception.
  • B: Projection would involve seeing HER unwanted traits in OTHERS. She sees herself IN others - a different mechanism.
  • D: Hallucinations and visual distortions are not normal aspects of performance anxiety.
